DataElement.preferredDefinition: Information related to the type of specimen used for the laboratory procedure.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting._A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis._Where something is available or from where it originates.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.:A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.

Concepts.definition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.
Where something is available or from where it originates.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: On or near an edge or constituting an outer boundary; the outer area.: A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.: The acid form of edetate, a chelating agent with anti-hypercalcemic and anticoagulant properties. Edetic acid binds calcium and heavy metal ions, forming soluble stable complexes which are readily excreted by the kidneys. This results in a decrease in serum calcium levels. This agent is also used as an anticoagulant for blood specimens and is applied as a treatment of lead poisoning.

Concepts.definition: On or near an edge or constituting an outer boundary; the outer area.

A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.

The acid form of edetate, a chelating agent with anti-hypercalcemic and anticoagulant properties. Edetic acid binds calcium and heavy metal ions, forming soluble stable complexes which are readily excreted by the kidneys. This results in a decrease in serum calcium levels. This agent is also used as an anticoagulant for blood specimens and is applied as a treatment of lead poisoning.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the father, coming from the father, or related through the father.: The watery fluid in the mouth made by the salivary glands. Saliva moistens food to help digestion and it helps protect the mouth against infections.

Concepts.definition: Having to do with the father, coming from the father, or related through the father.
The watery fluid in the mouth made by the salivary glands. Saliva moistens food to help digestion and it helps protect the mouth against infections.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.: The collection of cells from the inside of a person's cheek.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.
The collection of cells from the inside of a person's cheek using a swab collection device.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure that collects a component of the peripheral blood while returning the rest to the donor.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that collects a component of the peripheral blood while returning the rest to the donor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.

Concepts.definition: Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A piece of tissue cut on a microtome so that it rolls up on itself, giving it an appearance similar to a paper scroll.

Concepts.definition: A piece of tissue cut on a microtome so that it rolls up on itself, giving it an appearance similar to a paper scroll.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.

It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: To freeze rapidly so as to preserve structure and prevent ice crystal formation.: A tumor sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: To freeze rapidly so as to preserve structure and prevent ice crystal formation.

Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis.

PermissibleValues.value: Synaptophysin and GFAP IHC stained slides
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Synaptophysin And Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein Immunohistochemistry Staining Method Slide Device

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Synaptophysin And Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein Immunohistochemistry Staining Method Slide Device
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Synaptophysin (313 aa, ~34 kDa) is encoded by the human SYP gene. This protein is involved in the targeting of synaptic vesicles.: An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: Glial fibrillary acidic protein (432 aa, ~50 kDa) is encoded by the human GFAP gene. This protein may be involved in both neuronal maintenance and astrocyte morphology and motility.: Immunohistochemical staining techniques allow for the visualization of antigens via the sequential application of a specific antibody to the antigen (primary antibody), a secondary antibody to the primary antibody and an enzyme complex with a chromogenic substrate. The enzymatic activation of the chromogen results in a visible reaction product at the antigen site. The specimen may then be counterstained and coverslipped. Results are interpreted using a light microscope and aid in the differential diagnosis of pathophysiological processes, which may or may not be associated with a particular antigen.: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Concepts.definition: Synaptophysin (313 aa, ~34 kDa) is encoded by the human SYP gene. This protein is involved in the targeting of synaptic vesicles.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.
Glial fibrillary acidic protein (432 aa, ~50 kDa) is encoded by the human GFAP gene. This protein may be involved in both neuronal maintenance and astrocyte morphology and motility.

Immunohistochemical staining techniques allow for the visualization of antigens via the sequential application of a specific antibody to the antigen (primary antibody), a secondary antibody to the primary antibody and an enzyme complex with a chromogenic substrate. The enzymatic activation of the chromogen results in a visible reaction product at the antigen site. The specimen may then be counterstained and coverslipped. Results are interpreted using a light microscope and aid in the differential diagnosis of pathophysiological processes, which may or may not be associated with a particular antigen.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The best or most suitable; the greatest degree attainable.: A wound or cleft resulted from tissue separation into parts or laid open or penetrated with a sharp edge or instrument.: A measure of the average kinetic energy of a system of particles. Temperature may be quantified, in the context of thermodynamics, as the potential of one system to transfer thermal energy to another system until both systems reach a state of thermal equilibrium.: A substance formed by chemical union of two or more elements or ingredients in definite proportion by weight.: A tumor sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.

Concepts.definition: The best or most suitable; the greatest degree attainable.
A wound or cleft resulted from tissue separation into parts or laid open or penetrated with a sharp edge or instrument.

A substance formed by chemical union of two or more elements or ingredients in definite proportion by weight.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tuft of material on the end of a stick for applying solutions and suspensions

Concepts.definition: A tuft of material on the end of a stick for applying solutions and suspensions

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans._Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.

Concepts.definition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.
Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not previously used.: A specimen that has been subjected to and immobilized by severe cold.: An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.

Concepts.definition: Not previously used.
A specimen that has been subjected to and immobilized by severe cold.
An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Refers to a process where a sample is preserved with formalin and then embedded into a paraffin block for sectioning.: A piece of tissue cut on a microtome so that it rolls up on itself, giving it an appearance similar to a paper scroll.

Concepts.definition: Refers to a process where a sample is preserved with formalin and then embedded into a paraffin block for sectioning.
A piece of tissue cut on a microtome so that it rolls up on itself, giving it an appearance similar to a paper scroll.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A specimen prepared by spreading cells from bone marrow aspirate thinly on a glass slide for microscopic examination. The study of bone marrow smears is routinely used for the investigation, diagnosis, and staging of hematopoietic disorders.

Concepts.definition: A specimen prepared by spreading cells from bone marrow aspirate thinly on a glass slide for microscopic examination. The study of bone marrow smears is routinely used for the investigation, diagnosis, and staging of hematopoietic disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: On or near an edge or constituting an outer boundary; the outer area.: A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.

Concepts.definition: On or near an edge or constituting an outer boundary; the outer area.

Several hormones also travel in the blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

Concepts.definition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.: Fluid withdrawn from a lump, often a cyst, or a nipple.

Concepts.definition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.
Fluid withdrawn from a body cavity, organ, cyst, or tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: BONE MARROW BIOPSY

Concepts.definition: A biopsy involving the removal of a core tissue containing bone spicules and hematopoietic elements embedded in the marrow stroma.  This procedure is done in the hip area mainly for the diagnosis and evaluation of neoplastic and non-neoplastic hematopoietic disorders (e.g. anemias, leukemias, lymphomas) and the evaluation of the spread of solid tumors (e.g. carcinomas, sarcomas) and lymphomas for therapeutic purposes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The middle layer of an anticoagulated blood specimen following separation by centrifugation. It contains most of the white blood cells and platelets.: Any natural or synthetic composition that replicates the structure or function of a native component of blood.

Concepts.definition: The middle layer of an anticoagulated blood specimen following separation by centrifugation. It contains most of the white blood cells and platelets.
Any natural or synthetic composition that replicates the structure or function of a native component of blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.: Blocks; refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.

Concepts.definition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.
Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.  These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A vial used to store specimens in a cryopreservative at very low temperatures.

Concepts.definition: A vial used to store specimens in a cryopreservative at very low temperatures.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Paraffin is a common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily. (from Wikipedia): Blocks; refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.

Concepts.definition: A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.
Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.  These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining.

Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Slide Device Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Tissue

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Slide Device Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Tissue
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.: An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.

Concepts.definition: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.
An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Tumor Tissue Formalin-Fixed Paraffin-Embedded Fixed Block

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Tumor Tissue Formalin-Fixed Paraffin-Embedded Fixed Block
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tumor sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination.: Refers to a process where a sample is preserved with formalin and then embedded into a paraffin block for sectioning.: Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.  These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining.

Concepts.definition: Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis.
Refers to a process where a sample is preserved with formalin and then embedded into a paraffin block for sectioning.
Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.  These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Slide Device Tumor Tissue Formalin-Fixed Paraffin-Embedded Unstained Specimen

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Slide Device Tumor Tissue Formalin-Fixed Paraffin-Embedded Unstained Specimen
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.: A tumor sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination.: Refers to a process where a sample is preserved with formalin and then embedded into a paraffin block for sectioning.: A specimen that is mounted for microscopic study but without preparation methods which use dyes, reagents or other materials to produce coloration in tissues or microorganisms for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis.
Refers to a process where a sample is preserved with formalin and then embedded into a paraffin block for sectioning.

A specimen that is mounted for microscopic study but without preparation methods which use dyes, reagents or other materials to produce coloration in tissues or microorganisms for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A specimen that has been subjected to and immobilized by severe cold.: A tumor sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A specimen that has been subjected to and immobilized by severe cold.

Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A peripheral blood cell with a single nucleus. This category includes lymphocytes and monocytes.

Concepts.definition: A peripheral blood cell with a single nucleus. This category includes lymphocytes and monocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Tissue which has not been exposed to a fixative solution._A tumor sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: Tissue which has not been exposed to a fixative solution.

Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tissue sample that has been frozen prior to analysis.

Concepts.definition: A tissue sample that has been frozen prior to analysis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Immunohistochemical staining techniques allow for the visualization of antigens via the sequential application of a specific antibody to the antigen (primary antibody), a secondary antibody to the primary antibody and an enzyme complex with a chromogenic substrate. The enzymatic activation of the chromogen results in a visible reaction product at the antigen site. The specimen may then be counterstained and coverslipped. Results are interpreted using a light microscope and aid in the differential diagnosis of pathophysiological processes, which may or may not be associated with a particular antigen.

Concepts.definition: Immunohistochemical staining techniques allow for the visualization of antigens via the sequential application of a specific antibody to the antigen (primary antibody), a secondary antibody to the primary antibody and an enzyme complex with a chromogenic substrate. The enzymatic activation of the chromogen results in a visible reaction product at the antigen site. The specimen may then be counterstained and coverslipped. Results are interpreted using a light microscope and aid in the differential diagnosis of pathophysiological processes, which may or may not be associated with a particular antigen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Geimsa is a polychromatic stain that permits the differentiation of cells present in hematopoietic tissues and for the demonstration of certain microorganisms. It is used for the detection of helicobacter pylori. The H. pylori and nuclei stain dark blue and cytoplasm stain pink with this stain (From BioGenex).

Concepts.definition: Geimsa is a polychromatic stain that permits the differentiation of cells present in hematopoietic tissues and for the demonstration of certain microorganisms. It is used for the detection of helicobacter pylori. The H. pylori and nuclei stain dark blue and cytoplasm stain pink with this stain (From BioGenex).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A specimen that is mounted for microscopic study following preparation methods which use dyes, reagents, or other materials to produce coloration of cellular structures._A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Concepts.definition: A biospecimen that has been prepared using dyes, reagents, or other materials to produce coloration of structures.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A specimen that is mounted for microscopic study but without preparation methods which use dyes, reagents or other materials to produce coloration in tissues or microorganisms for microscopic examination._A microscope slide that lacks a positive surface charge.

Concepts.definition: A specimen that is mounted for microscopic study but without preparation methods which use dyes, reagents or other materials to produce coloration in tissues or microorganisms for microscopic examination.
A microscope slide that lacks a positive surface charge.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The material discharged from the bowel during defecation.  It consists of undigested food, intestinal mucus, epithelial cells, and bacteria.

Concepts.definition: The material discharged from the bowel during defecation.  It consists of undigested food, intestinal mucus, epithelial cells, and bacteria.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The liquid lying above a liquid, solid or semi-solid residue, which is separated by crystallization, precipitation or centrifugation of a cerebrospinal fluid sample.

Concepts.definition: The liquid lying above a liquid, solid or semi-solid residue, which is separated by crystallization, precipitation or centrifugation of a cerebrospinal fluid sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The fluid that is contained within the brain ventricles, the subarachnoid space and the central canal of the spinal cord._Formation by cetrifugation of a tightly packed sample in the bottom of a tube.

Concepts.definition: The fluid that is contained within the brain ventricles, the subarachnoid space and the central canal of the spinal cord.
Formation by cetrifugation of a tightly packed sample in the bottom of a tube.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Unstained Core Biopsy Slide

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Hematoxylin and Eosin Tissue Slide Core Biopsy
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tissue slide that has been stained with hematoxylin and eosin._The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: A tissue slide that has been stained with hematoxylin and eosin.
The removal of a tissue sample using a needle with a relatively large diameter, for microscopic examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Fresh Specimen Tumor Tissue Sample Within Sterile Media
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Tissue which has not been exposed to a fixative solution._Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis._On the inside; contained in._Devoid of living organisms._Any mechanism of mass communication.

Concepts.definition: Tissue which has not been exposed to a fixative solution.

Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis.
On the inside; contained in.
Devoid of living organisms.
Any mechanism of mass communication.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
